title: What will happen next regarding New York Governor Andrew Cuomo?
possible_answers: Cuomo will announce that he will not seek reelection as governor in 2022
Cuomo will either resign as governor or announce that he will resign as governor
Cuomo will be removed from office by an impeachment trial
None of these will occur before 1 April 2022
correct_answer: Cuomo will either resign as governor or announce that he will resign as governor
preds: Cuomo has announced that he's stepping aside

As the surroundings implode, so will Cuomo.  Time's up! https://www.nbcnews.com/nbc-out/out-news/prominent-lgbtq-leaders-face-increased-scrutiny-cuomo-report-rcna1633
https://timesupfoundation.org/newsroom/times-up-speaks-out-organization-holds-itself-accountable-kaplan-steps-aside/ +4 in Bin 2.

- He's trying to cut a deal to stay on for the remainder of his term (https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/us/cuomo-trying-to-cut-a-deal-to-avoid-impeachment-source-says/ar-AAN6Uve)
- Lt Gov making her takeover plans (https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/new-york-lt-gov-kathy-hochul-is-preparing-to-take-over-for-andrew-cuomo-report/ar-AAN6s92) Increasing chances that a resignation will occur.

My priors here are that Cuomo is extraordinarily stubborn and scornful of public opinion, executive office holders of both parties have learned they can just wait out scandals in an era of non-stop news and fickle public concern. Reporting suggests the margin for error in impeaching Cuomo is minimal: https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2021/08/cuomo-impeachment-democrats-say-it-needs-to-be-perfect.html I have the impression of Cuomo that he would look at resignation as admission of guilt, which he emphatically will not want to do. He wants to hold onto office, and baring that, have opponents he can rail against to deflect attention from his own alleged improprieties.

Melissa DeRosa, Cuomo's top aide and confidante, resigned tonight. She was involved in helping cover the full extent of the nursing homes deaths at the height of the pandemic and also led efforts to retaliated against the first woman who accused the governor of sexual harassment. I think this increases the odds of the governor resigning instead of waiting to be impeached but Mr Cuomo's hubris is big enough to fight the inevitable to the end before quitting.

Cuomo is going to try to cut a deal. Promising not to run in 2022 won't be enough, but he may try it before resigning. He gains nothing by forcing the legislature to impeach him which it will do if he does not resign. https://apnews.com/article/andrew-cuomo-joe-biden-impeachments-albany-criminal-investigations-acf17b3a26774a4f4559b8088de52999
also, https://www.thecity.nyc/2021/8/9/22616581/cuomo-impeachment-seeking-deal
Well, I wish I didn't enter this one.  I'm really unsure what to do here.
first polling shows 70% of new yorkers think he should resign, but i believe he will wait it out and see if people lose interest and move on....

HIs own party wants him gone - something will happen. Removing any chance of 4th bin.
Sorry, I thought I had an independently different forecast from my last one based on new information but it turns out my probabilities haven't changed.

Nobody can make Cuomo resign, and his history and personality do not arouse hope that he will do so.  There are probably enough votes in the Assembly to impeach him, but they'll need some pretend deliberations as they prepare to file, docket, and vote on the articles.   The Honourable Members will have to fit this carnival in with other legislative business and also take the usual long and frequent breaks from their exertions.   Once they get him impeached, maybe not before October or so, the matter goes over to the Court for the Trial of Impeachments, which is the State Senate (minus the President Pro Tem, who is in the succession and so presumptively interested), augmented by the judges of the Court of Appeals (the state's Supreme Court). Two thirds of this gang must vote to convict.   As it happens, exactly two thirds of the current Senate are Ds, and all of the Court of Appeals judges (who serve 14-year terms) are Cuomo appointees.   They will wish to  distinguish their procedures from those of the President-Eject's sock puppets, so they will take their time pretending to decide what to do. Meanwhile, young Andrew will pull out all the stops to cajole, threaten, or suborn some of the Senate Ds into either voting for acquittal or going to visit a sick aunt on the day of the vote.  But after impeachment, the Lieutenant Governor becomes Acting Governor until the impeachment is resolved or the Governor's term expires; this may decrease Handy Andy's influence at that point in the festivities. LG Kathy Hochul is generally better liked than Cuomo, as is most of humanity, and is regarded as very smart, very tough, quite a good campaigner, and shall we say flexible in policy matters.   She immediately becomes the front-runner to succeed him if he is gone for the '22 election.   There is no imaginable Republican candidate who can be elected Governor of New York in the foreseeable future, although some other offices might be secured by comparatively attractive R candidates.  Therefore, if were the New York Republicans, I'd have to decide whether the down-ticket is better served by having Kathy Hochul automatically at the head of the D ticket, with a fairly distinguished record even before acquiring gubernatorial experience as Regent, or Hochul or another D going through a bruising primary campaign if Merry Andrew decides to run again, as he might well?  If the latter, I might vote not to convict him in the Senate.   I still wouldn't take the Mansion, but I could get the opposition to start eating their young and build up my farm team.  The punch line, if there is one, is that it is improbable that this will all play out before next April.   Full disclosure:  I am not the New York Republicans, but only one of them--and not one of the ones that matters, either.  It would be best to pay no attention to this musing, or at least drop in at the off-licence first.

So that's one thing I will look into - is there any data to use to predict how likely impeachment trial success if attempted.   Sounds like lot of allegations.  So pressure will be put on him.  So far he appears to have no intention of resigning.  And if he wants to avoid public disgrace, it's already past that time - he would had resigned months ago. I have admit I don't understand this.  Why would someone sexual harrass and then why would he not feel enough guilt or shame or something to take action and resign or something.   And I don't understand the appeal of Cuomo.  I'm not a New Yorker and I don't understand the appeal of someone with so abrasive personality as Cuomo has.  But I guess New Yorkers kind of like that style.
This is a very interesting question.  But I have no idea and so to indicate that all outcomes equal.

I'm starting to see that the Dems need Cuomo gone - they can’t afford to give the Republican contestant for Governor next year any extra ammo.  My guess is he will be pressured into stepping down and save himself from impeachment but he's still very defensive and holding his position for now.

The impeachment process is speeding up and it sounds like there may be enough opposition for him to be impeached now. I'm leaning to favor the middle two buckets with the thought process that Cuomo may resign if he looks likely to be impeached. https://twitter.com/studentactivism/status/1422669833431302148 https://www.npr.org/2021/08/04/1024833937/new-york-state-lawmakers-prepare-for-impeachment-proceedings-of-gov-andrew-cuomo

"None of these will occur" -- Part of prediction making is looking at history. Delaying has worked well for Cuomo in the past, including this year when he refused to resign in March and his poll numbers gradually went back up due to his Covid response and the passage of time. Resignation -- By all accounts, Andrew Cuomo is not the type of guy who will resign out of a sense of guilt or shame the way Eliot Spitzer did, so my best guess after studying this pretty intensely is that it's 10% or maybe 15% at the most. President Biden has said Cuomo should resign, but he has also said he's not calling Cuomo on the phone to tell him to resign: https://www.foxnews.com/politics/biden-cuomo-call-sexual-harassment-impeachment-resignation-psaki It's best for Democrats politically if they can loudly condemn Cuomo, but then he just quietly serves out his term and goes quietly into the night. From a cold, calculating perspective that someone like Cuomo uses, it's best to stay in office as long as possible, with the criminal investigations ongoing. If he were to resign he would be giving away a lot of his bargaining chips. I can't see what he'd gain from resigning, unless it's as part of a deal to avoid prosecution. Announcing he won't seek reelection --  This seems a given, due to the polling: http://maristpoll.marist.edu/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/Marist-Poll_NYS-NOS-and-Tables_202108040647-2.pdf#page=3  Please see page 6 -- only 18% of Democrats think he should be reelected.  So making that announcement would reduce the pressure on him to resign and would reduce impeachment pressure. (I could easily imagine some legislators in safely blue districts saying, "With the pandemic ongoing and continuity of government being so important...")

Everything feels to be on the table and the impeachment process could be swift. Granted, status quo will likely prevail, this is a moment of delicious uncertainty. https://open.spotify.com/episode/64ZulgPoftYl3J6rSukm1A?si=4ZPCMokLRNiy8KQAJ3Pj1w&dl_branch=1
Biden is saying he should resign. Reducing confidence in the last bucket on the latest news.

Cuomo is as defiant and unrepentant as ever. I'm increasing the probability of impeachment because of remarks made by Speaker Carl Heastie: “the Governor has lost the confidence of the Assembly Democratic majority and that he can no longer remain in office.” However, it's far from clear that the Assembly has any timeline for finishing their own investigation or starting impeachment proceedings, and whether the votes are there to remove Cuomo from office.

NYT reporting that Assembly Speaker, Carl Heastie, says "they will move expeditiously and look to conclude impeachment investigation as quickly as possible" 
Haeastie wouldn't move quick enough on impeachment regarding nursing home deaths and other decisions Cuomo made at the height of the pandemic but they will move quickly on sexual harassment report.  "Under the New York constitution, the State Assembly has to vote by a simple majority to impeach the governor. Then the case goes over to the State Senate for trial. A Siena Poll released July 1 showed 23% of New Yorkers saying he should resign immediately, 39% saying he should serve out his term but not seek re-election, and 33% saying he should continue to serve and run for re-election." We'll have to see how these numbers change after today's report. "When it came to impeachment, voters a month ago were more closely divided with 45%, a plurality, saying the Assembly should not impeach Cuomo, while 35% – including one-quarter of Democrats – would like to see the Assembly impeach the governor." https://www.news10.com/news/what-would-it-take-to-impeach-gov-cuomo/

Pres. Biden just said Cuomo should resign after NY AG made her report on sexual harassment investigation public. Cuomo is going to fight, foolishly, but it's going to take some time for him to realize he's toxic and he cannot mend the damage done. He was able to stay afloat all this time, in part because the party itself let him run with it as they worked on negotiating the budget then buying some time for the report to be completed. But they all had to know. It's another shrewd political game. Things are so bad in NY that de Blasio now thinks he can run for governor.

Report of the Attorney-General says the Guv has been and remains a serial jerk.   No one is surprised by this.  Nonetheless, there will be much pearl-clutching in the New York State Assembly, followed almost immediately by outraged outrage from the Rs while the Ds pretend to be dead.  If this sounds familiar, the rehearsal for it was two remarkably similar episodes down in DC over the past several years, from the other side of the aisle.  Political cowardice is not a partisan monopoly.   Nothing is likely to happen before this Q expires, though.  Still, slightly upping the odds that Merry Andrew won't run again.  He will wish to spend more time with his family, who do not necessarily wish the same thing.  The Ds will have to scramble some to round up a successor, but somebody will get anointed and will win.   Cuomo will write a book (or rather, will pay somebody to write a book in his name).  Too many people will buy it.  One would be too many.

I regret not pinpointing which of my previous forecasts included base rates. It was hard work and I'm probably not going to render the same percentages if I tried again. This update adjusts back to my gut feelings, putting myself into the governor's shoes if I were to resign. However, I have a hunch that it is more likely to resign than announce you are not running for re-election; I think resignations are far more common than admitting that you are powerless and not running. On the other hand, the Dept. of Justice announced it would not pursue an investigation into Cuomo's COVID scandals.

Talking to a number of New Yorkers over the past week, the solid consensus is that the state General Assembly is in disarray and does not have the ability, at least at the moment, to mount an impeachment.  Additionally, they are fairly confident that unless the emerging scandals really heat up and are compounded by additional scandals it is highly unlikely Cuomo will resign.  Unanimous agreement was that he will not seek re-election.  Of course, these are just opinion, but all of these people are involved in some level of New York politics, Democratic and Republican.  Making slight modifications in my forecast as a result.

While issues are piling up for Governor Cuomo (i.e. more sexual harassment allegations, COVID nursing home scandal, increased unpopularity, etc.), considering his statements and personality, at the moment, it remains unlikely he will resign.  Impeachment does not appear to be gaining enough traction at the moment.  The most likely outcome by April 1st is Cuomo announces he is not seeking re-election in 2022.  I am reducing my "None" forecast slightly to reallocate to "resign" and "removed" based on the increase pressures Cuomo is facing and to account for unforeseen issues that may arise later in the year.

In addition, he is blessed with boundless arrogance and a firm faith in the tendency of his constituents to vote Democrat no matter what.   It will be difficult for even a reasonably attractive R, if there still were any, to win statewide office here.  One or two Ds will mount a loud but fruitless intra-party squall.  It will die down and he will be re-elected.  Think of New Yorkers as Texans with better pizza.

The Honourable Gentleman says he's being persecuted because he's not in with the political In Crowd.  This may not work:  His daddy was the Governor; he was a member of Clinton's cabinet; and he is married to a Kennedy.   On the other hand, he saw the Big Lie work for the President-Eject and may think it will serve him as well.  One might point out politely that it didn't work for M. Petits-Doigts in New York. On the other hand, no Republican is going to get elected Governor here for a while, so The Kid will see no reason to step aside if he thinks he can bully his party into granting him the nomination again.  He is hampered in this by two facts:  (1) Nobody in Albany ever liked him very much, and even less these days; and (2) he is blissfully unaware of that.   Kathy Hochul, the LG, is generally regarded as a fairly nice person, so impeachment and conviction mayn't seem unattractive.  (Once upon a time when Calvin Coolidge was LG of Massachusetts, he introduced himself to a woman by saying, "Hello, I'm Calvin Coolidge, the Lieutenant Governor."  "And what do you do?" she inquired.  He replied, "I just did it.")
If there will be more pressure from the party he might resign (unlikely) , but hard to see him seek re-election
He's a swine, and will use the public's money for his own defense,  for as long as he can.

Cuomo seems unlikely to be reelected given that a majority of New Yorkers want him to resign. Still, if he were going to resign, he probably would have already. The most likely scenario would seem one in which Cuomo allows someone else to seek the governorship in 2022 by not seeking reelection during the democratic primary process. https://www.forbes.com/sites/tommybeer/2021/03/19/new-poll-suggests-majority-of-new-yorkers-say-gov-cuomo-should-resign/?sh=4b0bebfd1f33

Cuomo has no intention of resigning, but if additional information comes out he might be forced to admit he will not seek re-election. But his ego will not have him voluntarily step down. Saying he won't seek re-election is the closest thing we will get to an admission of wrongdoing.

New York Attorney General Leticia James' is busy! She is / will be coordinating with NYS and federal investigators regarding Trump, in addition to Cuomo's mishandling of covid-19 in nursing homes and allegations of harassment of female members of his staff. It will be late 2020 (at least) before any announcements are made on the Cuomo investigations. Cuomo will have time to ride out this quiet period while the investigations are underway and later will announce that he will decline to run again in lieu of a reelection campaign. Cuomo knows that a reelection campaign will damn his legacy if AG James' investigations don't damn him first.

Resignation seems likely. While he has enough popularity with NY Democrats to avoid impeachment, there is a slightly greater chance he could face pressure from the establishment to resign for the party's sake. 
Cuomo lacks complete support and has a toxic glow to his name, which will certainly cost him support from all of the younger demographic and make him all but unelectable. Without party support, it will be financially beneficial for him to resign and keep his war chest versus spending it all on a fruitless election attempt.
